text: so this question whether or not there's
generational differences I I think it at
the broad brush level I think that all
human groups and and the research shows
anthropological research going back to
pre-industrial times we actually all
want the same kind of leader but the
nuances are different depending on the
generation what we want it turns out is
we want a boss who is competent and not
selfish or benevolent so in the book I
described this as as a boss who is good
at performance getting performance out
of people training them supporting them
and and doing their job well and
supports dignity and respect and so the
idea of having confidence and
benevolence or confidence and compassion
you can see that all through research
going way back those are the people who
attend to rise to the leadership
positions in pre-industrial tribes and
those are the people who we also want as
our leaders so at the most abstract
level that's who that's who we want to
lead us as human beings but but at
different times the question of what
somebody who's got your back or is
compassionate I think that gets
reinterpreted so so one of the issues
that the Millennials have which for
example my parent my parents didn't have
and and in even my generation to a
lesser extent is that um first of all
they they want to both men and women
want to be more involved than raising
their kids if they have kids so in that
case uh having a job where you're
working 75 hours a week doesn't work out
too well for everyone and another thing
that's happened with the Millennials
that's different than their parents or
even to some extent my generation and I
definitely see this at Stanford with my
students is boy did I see it the last
couple of years is is in my family and
other families you'd see that somebody
would work for a large corporation for
years and it would be okay but what's
happened to their parents is well
they've learned and they always say the
man it's funny they've learned not to
trust the man that the man's going to
screw them in the end
and in fact that's the new employment
contract so so it always sort of amazes
me when I see Executives from Big
corporations and they say I don't know
why they don't trust me well you've been
layoffs are at all-time high and in fact
there's evidence it isn't just the
economic Times that layoffs are becoming
a more an increasingly um an
increasingly sort of um frequent
response to economic troubles they
happen quicker and they happen deeper
and then there there's fewer
organizations with Pension Plan
essentially the employment contract has
changed so so my perspective on the
Millennials is no wonder you act that
way you you've been taught that the
man's going to screw you or sometimes
the woman if you're working for somebody
like Meg Whitman or something or Karly
finina who actually laid off lots of
people Meg didn't lay off very many
people um so so so in some ways um the
Millennials are acting completely
rational and and therefore I guess the
the definition of a competent and
compassionate boss changes it's it's
somebody who um is skilled at um giving
you
uh the skills and abilities and
connections you need to continue
throughout your career even after they
fire you um so so I I I do think that
relationship has has changed some and I
I I guess that the definition of a nice
boss is nastier than it used to be you
can you can be known as nice and still
do pretty nasty things to
people so the notion is and and as a
business book author I should probably
make the argument you should buy my book
and all your problems are solved but
anybody who tells you that by taking
this class or reading my book you will
magically become a good boss is lying to
you um but but the analogy I use is a
little bit like medicine that um that
what you want is a doctor who both has a
lot of
experience and a doctor who actually
knows what the latest research is
because experience is sort of a
dangerous teacher in some ways it's good
to have the craft knowledge but you also
need to sort of leev that with with the
mistakes that many other people have
made in more systematic um evidence and
and so I think you sort of need the one
two punch of both of them and and one
thing that really does strike me is that
um some of the most effective and
impressive um bosses and managers to me
are people who are hungry to get as much
experience as possible so I think that's
true for the Millennials anybody else
who takes a job you want to have as much
different sort of management experience
as possible and also hungry to sort of
if you will consume information from
diverse sources so as as I guess the
quote the Elanor Roosevelt quote I use
in the book is that uh is that it's good
to learn from other people's mistakes
because you can't live long enough to
make all those mistakes yourself and um
although there's an argument from
learning for from your own mistakes so
to me it's sort of a balance between the
two and and very much um especially over
the years I've sort of developed this
notion that um that management is it's a
craft and I think I think medicine is an
appropriate comparison where you can
practice the craft better if you know
the best research but if you haven't
done it um there's no way to learn about
it by the way that's one thing I do like
about
startups and and teaching Stanford a lot
of the students go into startups is when
you go into a startup you're thrown in
the sort of the belly of the Beast and
you get to do all this management stuff
that you're in a big Corporation you be
protected from and in fact I think that
some of the best employees of of big
corporations I'm thinking of like uh
Facebook which is actually pretty big
and um Google and stuff some of the best
managers they have are people who have
sort of like grown that startup and
they'll Chas against the larger
bureaucracy to some extent but but they
sort of know what it takes to make
things worth work so I'm I'm a big
believer that for for sort of first job
out of school that's starting your own
business even if you fail it'll it'll
have all sorts of rewards the rest of
your life in terms of being able to get
stuff done because you actually get
practice doing management type
stuff there's no way that people can um
can learn without failing and if you can
show me a situation I would love to see
the situation where just magically you
can parachute in and be instantly lucky
and Brilliant and and and and you know I
think think of some of the heroes of our
day from Steve Jobs to Mark Zuckerberg
and stuff and right right now
Zuckerberg's like a bit of a darling and
a bit of an enemy with he's CEO of
Facebook but like they've made enormous
number of mistakes and and Facebook's a
good example because some of us may
remember a couple years back they had
this thing come out where automatically
if you just went to a restaurant or
anything you did with s like show up on
your Facebook or you bought something it
would show up on your Facebook page and
God knows people were probably buying
you know pornography or whatever just
sort of like show up on on their
Facebook page unless they stopped it
well that those sort of mistakes
actually are part of the process of
learning and and Zuckerberg is an
interesting example because uh although
although he's a controversial character
he definitely has the guts to try stuff
um that might offend people but also um
sort of push the envelope but so the the
argument that that I've made about
failures and bosses though in some ways
to to to um oversimplify it um when I
think about failure there's three
General sorts of responses that emerge
from both the management literature and
practice the first one is what I call
the forgive and forget approach and so
just I'm going to see my uh teenage
daughter after that she's now in college
but uh an example of the forgive and
forget approach is uh so the first
actually day she had her Learners permit
through a series of events I still don't
understand she ran my wife's brand new
Infinity so had 300 mil in it into our
house and did um $2,000 wor the damage
to the car and $500 wor the damage to
the house and her reaction was she
wanted us to forgive her and to forget
about it and the problem with forgive
and forget is there's like no
accountability and there's no learning
the second approach is what I call the
Silicon Valley standard this is remember
blame stigmatize ostracize and humiliate
um and the problem with that is that uh
is that when you sort of humiliate
people or put them down when they fail
fail then they're afraid to admit
mistakes and and the whole world turns
into a cover your ass sort of game so no
learning occurs and the way that the
most effective organizations and in fact
if you look at research on hospitals
that learn from medical mistakes this is
the this is sort of the Mantra they
sometimes use it's to forgive and
remember so you forgive to have some
psychological safety and remember so
that you can learn from your own
mistakes and other people's mistakes and
the other reason you remember is that if
people keep making the same mistakes
over and over again and then there's
some accountability and it's a sign
you've kind of got to get rid of them or
have them do something else but uh but
failure is a complicated thing and just
as a final point about failure um Tom
Peters and on down management theorists
I guess including me have celebrated the
virtues of failure but it's but one
thing that I'm always very careful to
say is I don't like failure I think it
sucks it's a terrible thing I wish it
wasn't necessary but I can't figure out
any other way for people to learn how to
do most things but to sort of screw up
enough till the point where they get
better at it
